Based on the following diagnostic criteria and drug list, make diagnosis and medication recommendations. Output format:
Patient's hypertension status explanation: xxxxx
Recommended medications, dosage, and reasons: xxxxxx
Potential side effects to monitor: xxxxxxxx
Target blood pressure, medication evaluation period, and rare precautions: xxxxxx
Disclaimer: xxxx

Diagnostic criteria as follows:
Blood Pressure Level Assessment and Classification


Mild Hypertension (140-159/90-99 mmHg)
Moderate Hypertension (160-179/100-109 mmHg)
Severe Hypertension (≥180/110 mmHg)


Patient Characteristics Consideration:


Age:

≥65 years elderly: Prefer CCB or diuretics, avoid dramatic pressure reduction
Middle-aged: All first-line medications are optional
<55 years young: Can prioritize ACEI/ARB


Gender:

Women of childbearing age: ACEI/ARB contraindicated
Post-menopausal women: Watch for osteoporosis risk, use diuretics with caution




Initial Medication Principles:


Mild Hypertension: Start with single drug at low dose
Moderate to Severe Hypertension: Consider low-dose combination therapy
Systolic >20mmHg or Diastolic >10mmHg above target: Consider dual therapy


Special Conditions Consideration:


Isolated Systolic Hypertension: Prefer CCB or diuretics
With Heart Failure: Prefer ACEI/ARB + β-blockers
With Diabetes: Prioritize ACEI/ARB
With Renal Dysfunction: Prioritize ACEI/ARB (unless severe renal impairment)


Monitoring and Adjustment Principles:


Evaluate efficacy and tolerability after 2 weeks of initial treatment
Consider adjusting regimen if target not reached within 4-6 weeks
Monitor electrolytes and renal function
Pay attention to patient compliance and lifestyle improvements

Drug List as follows:

Calcium Channel Blockers (CCB)


Amlodipine: Reduces BP 8-12/4-6 mmHg (systolic/diastolic)
Main side effects: Ankle edema, headache, facial flushing, tachycardia
Interactions: Avoid with grapefruit juice; use with caution with β-blockers, may worsen cardiac conduction block


Angiotensin Converting Enzyme Inhibitors (ACEI)


Captopril/Enalapril: Reduces BP 8-12/4-8 mmHg
Main side effects: Dry cough (10-20% patients), hyperkalemia, angioedema
Interactions: Contraindicated with ARB; avoid with potassium-sparing diuretics; contraindicated in pregnancy


Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARB)


Valsartan/Telmisartan: Reduces BP 8-11/5-7 mmHg
Main side effects: Dizziness, hyperkalemia (lower incidence than ACEI)
Interactions: Contraindicated with ACEI; avoid with potassium-sparing diuretics; contraindicated in pregnancy


Thiazide Diuretics


Hydrochlorothiazide: Reduces BP 9-13/4-6 mmHg
Main side effects: Hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia
Interactions: Avoid with glucocorticoids; may increase lithium toxicity risk when combined with lithium


β-Blockers


Metoprolol/Bisoprolol: Reduces BP 8-10/6-8 mmHg
Main side effects: Fatigue, bradycardia, bronchospasm, masks hypoglycemia symptoms
Interactions: Avoid with verapamil-type calcium channel blockers; monitor blood glucose when used with insulin/sulfonylurea hypoglycemic agents
